required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

brief_summary.textblock: This study tests the hypothesis that modifying the media diet of preschool children so that they watch more prosocial programming and less violent programming will result in decreased aggression and increased prosocial behavior.

primary_outcome.measure: Social Competence and Behavioral Evaluation (SCBE) scores overall
primary_outcome.description: Overall Social Competence and Behavioral Evaluation (SCBE) scores will be assessed

primary_outcome.measure: Social Competence and Behavioral Evaluation (SCBE) aggression subscale
primary_outcome.description: Aggression, from the Social Competence and Behavioral Evaluation (SCBE) subscale scores, will be assessed at 6,

primary_outcome.measure: Social Competence and Behavioral Evaluation (SCBE) prosocial subscale
primary_outcome.description: Prosocial, from the Social Competence and Behavioral Evaluation (SCBE) subscale scores, will be assessed

secondary_outcome.description: The investigator will use elements of the sleep problem questionnaire to assess sleep problems

arm_group.description: advice tips and tools to reduce exposure to violent programming

intervention.description: advice and tips and tools for healthy non violent TV viewing

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 2.5-4 years of age
- watches TV regularly
- English speaking
Exclusion Criteria:
- no TV
- non English
